name: Mean
definition: most common measure of central tendency; the average of a set of numbers
label: mean
explanatoryNote: When unqualified, the mean usually refers to the expectation of a variate, or to the arithmetic mean of a sample used as an estimate of the expectation.

name: StatisticalMeasure
definition: summary (means, mode, total, index, etc.) of the individual quantitative variable values for the statistical units in a specific group (study domain)
label: statistical measure
explanatoryNote: Statistical measures may consist of several orthogonal characteristics, including (a) whether they reflect an estimate or variable, (b) the datatype, or from a FIBO perspective, nature of the measure (e.g., index, total, ratio, percent, percent change, mean, others), (c) the population (or the universe that applies to the highest level if defined in general) to which the measure applies, and (d) any relevant aspects used to subset or stratify a measure, (i.e., make them apply to a smaller universe).

name: StatisticalProgram
definition: program that presents a detailed investigation and analysis of a subject or situation involving one or more studies or surveys
label: statistical program

name: StatisticalUniverse
definition: collection representing the total membership, or 'universe', of people, resources, products, services, events, or entities of interest for some question, experiment, survey or statistical program
label: statistical universe

name: ScopedMeasure
definition: qualified measure that is constrained by filters on the statistical population to which it applies
explanatoryNote: Note that (1) the anchor date reflects the start of the current series, such as 1982-1984 for the CPI, (2) the fixed comparative date might be something like March 2009, if one is comparing a current index against its value at the end of the great recession, (3) the relative comparative date might be something like a month or year ago, depending on the analysis requirements, and (4) the relative comparative period might be a 3 month average prior value, again depending on the analysis requirements.
label: scoped measure

name: QualifiedMeasure
definition: statistical measure that is constrained by features, quantity kinds or units that refine how it is calculated
label: qualified measure

name: AverageAbsoluteDeviation
explanatoryNote: The central point can be the mean, median, mode, or the result of another measure of central tendency. Absolute deviation is the distance between each value in the data set and that data set's mean or median.
label: average absolute deviation
definition: average of the absolute deviations from a central point

name: Dispersion
explanatoryNote: It is usually measured as an average deviation about some central value (e.g. mean deviation, standard deviation) or by an order statistic (e.g. quartile deviation, range) but may also be a mean of deviations of values among themselves (e.g. Gini's mean difference and also standard deviation).
label: dispersion
definition: degree of scatter or variability shown by observations

name: NumericIndexValue
label: numeric index value
explanatoryNote: A mathematical device or number which is used to express the observation (e.g., price level, volume of trade, relative amount etc.) of a given period, in comparison with that of a prior period.
definition: numeric value of some aggregate relative to the value of that aggregate as of some date

name: GeometricMean
label: geometric mean
definition: mean that indicates the central tendency or typical value of a set of numbers by using the product of their values (as opposed to the arithmetic mean which uses their sum)
explanatoryNote: The geometric mean is defined as the nth root of the product of n numbers. A geometric mean is often used when comparing different items - finding a single 'figure of merit' for these items - when each item has multiple properties that have different numeric ranges. For example, the geometric mean can give a meaningful 'average' to compare two companies which are each rated at 0 to 5 for their environmental sustainability, and are rated at 0 to 100 for their financial viability. If an arithmetic mean were used instead of a geometric mean, the financial viability is given more weight because its numeric range is larger - so a small percentage change in the financial rating (e.g. going from 80 to 90) makes a much larger difference in the arithmetic mean than a large percentage change in environmental sustainability (e.g. going from 2 to 5).

name: Variance
label: variance
definition: measure of spread, calculated as the average squared deviation of each number from the mean of a data set

name: KeyPerformanceIndicator
explanatoryNote: Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are the critical (key) quantifiable indicators of progress toward an intended result. KPIs provide a focus for strategic and operational improvement, create an analytical basis for decision making and help focus attention on what matters most. Managing with the use of KPIs includes setting targets (the desired level of performance) and tracking progress against those targets.
label: key performance indicator
definition: measurable target that indicates how an individual or business is performing in terms of meeting its goals

name: StatisticalPopulation
explanatoryNote: A common aim of statistical analysis is to produce information about some chosen population. In statistical inference, a subset of the population (a statistical sample) is chosen to represent the population in a statistical analysis. If a sample is chosen properly, characteristics of the entire population that the sample is drawn from can be estimated from corresponding characteristics of the sample.
label: statistical population
definition: statistical universe filtered by time and region

name: FinitePopulation
label: finite population
explanatoryNote: In statistics, a population is a set of similar items or events of interest for some question or experiment. In other words, a population is the complete group of units to which survey results are to apply. (These units may be persons, animals, objects, businesses, trips, etc.). See
definition: population for which it is possible to count its units

name: AnnualizedStandardDeviation
label: annualized standard deviation
explanatoryNote: Standard deviation applied to the annual rate of return of an investment provides insights on the historical volatility of that investment. The greater the standard deviation of the price of a security, the greater the volatility. Multiplying monthly standard deviation by the square root of twelve (12) is an industry standard method of approximating annualized standard deviations of monthly returns.
definition: standard deviation for some measure over a specific reference period

name: StandardDeviation
definition: square root of variance that measures the spread or dispersion around the mean of a data set
explanatoryNote: While standard deviation is the most widely-used measure of spread, using squared deviations, it may not be the most robust.
label: standard deviation

name: Median
explanatoryNote: The basic advantage of the median in describing data compared to the mean is that it is not skewed by extremely large or small values, and may provide a better idea of a 'typical' value.
label: median
definition: value of the variate dividing the total frequency of a data sample, population, or probability distribution, into two halves

name: MedianAbsoluteDeviation
label: median absolute deviation
definition: median of the absolute deviations of observations from the average which may be the arithmetic mean, the median or the mode

name: Difference
label: difference
definition: quantity by which amounts differ; the remainder left after subtraction of one value from another

name: ArithmeticMean
definition: sum of a collection of numbers divided by the number of numbers in the collection
label: arithmetic mean
explanatoryNote: While the arithmetic mean is often used to report central tendencies, it is not a robust statistic, meaning that it is greatly influenced by outliers (values that are very much larger or smaller than most of the values). Notably, for skewed distributions, such as the distribution of income for which a few people's incomes are substantially greater than most people's, the arithmetic mean may not accord with one's notion of 'middle', and robust statistics, such as the median, may be a better description of central tendency.

name: StatisticalArea
label: statistical area
definition: physical location that is defined per some program for designating geographic regions for the purposes of tabulating and presenting statistical data

name: WeightingFunction
definition: expression or function that determines the relative importance or influence of a given element of a set with respect to the whole
explanatoryNote: With respect to discrete calculations, weighting functions are positive functions defined on discrete sets, such as weighted sums and weighted averages.
label: weighting function

name: StatisticalAreaIdentifier
definition: identifier for a physical location that is defined per a nationally consistent program for designating geographic regions for the purposes of tabulating and presenting statistical data
label: statistical area identifier

name: Formula
label: formula
definition: rule expressed in letters and symbols that consists of at least one expression

name: SamplingVariance
explanatoryNote: The word 'sampling' can usually be omitted, as being defined by the context or otherwise understood. The sampling variance of a statistic is the square of its standard error.
definition: measure of the extent to which the estimate of a characteristic from different possible samples of the same size and the same design differ from one another
label: sampling variance

name: hasFixedComparativeDate
definition: specifies the a specific date, such as the end of the last recession (e.g., March 2009) against which the scoped measure is compared
label: has fixed comparative date

name: hasRelativeComparativePeriod
label: has relative comparative period
definition: specifies a period (typically a prior period) against which the scoped measure is compared, such as an average set of values for some period of time compared with a more recent or projected average for a forward looking period of time

name: hasReleaseDateTime
definition: specifies the date and time on which something is published
label: has release date and time

name: hasUniverseSize
label: has universe size
definition: indicates the number of elements in a given universe

name: isEstimate
definition: indicates whether the measure reflects an estimate (approximation) or not
label: is estimate

name: hasObservedValue
explanatoryNote: For certain calculations, such as certain measures of dispersion, date value pairs are expected as input, in other words, a dated structured collection.
label: has observed value
definition: specifies a collection of values over which some analysis is performed

name: hasMeasurementDateTime
label: has measurement date time
definition: indicates the date and time that the measurement was taken

name: hasFormula
label: has formula
definition: specifies a concise way of expressing information symbolically, as in a mathematical or chemical formula

name: hasTargetValue
definition: specifies a collection of values that represent planned or projected goals or objectives for some something over time
label: has target value

name: hasNumberOfEntries
label: has number of entries
definition: indicates the number of elements in some document, table, or other resource (e.g., in a report, table)

name: hasPeriodicity
definition: specifies a recurrence interval (monthly, quarterly, annual) that a statistical measure reflects
label: has periodicity

name: hasPopulationSize
definition: indicates the number of elements in a given population
label: has population size

name: hasSubtrahend
label: has subtrahend
definition: specifies the quantity value that is subtracted from something

name: hasRelativeComparativeDate
definition: specifies a date against which the value of a scoped measure is compared (e.g., one month prior, three months prior, etc., and typically against a prior release or average over prior releases)
label: has relative comparative date

name: isCalculatedViaMethodology
definition: high-level description of the approach taken to obtain the result
label: is calculated via methodology

name: hasMinuend
label: has minuend
definition: specifies the quantity value from which something is subtracted; the value that is diminished

name: hasReferencePeriod
definition: specifies a reference (baseline) recurrence interval for which a given measure applies
label: has reference period

name: hasReleaseDate
definition: specifies the date on which something is published
explanatoryNote: A release date is typically a date fixed in advance for the release of a film, recording, document, report, or product or publication.
label: has release date

name: hasWeight
definition: indicates an amount given to increase or decrease the importance of an item
label: has weight

name: hasMeasurementPeriodInMonths
definition: indicates the coverage period for which the measure is applicable expressed in months
label: has measurement period in months
